summary: current therapy targets viral proteins, neuraminidase and M2, but is hampered by development of resistance. the cleavage of the influenza virus hemagglutinin (HA) by host cell proteases is essential for viral infectivity. deletion of Tmprss2 in knock-out mice strongly limits virus spread and lung pathology after H1N1 influenza A virus infection. non-infected Tmprss2 knock-out mice did not show a phenotype in the absence of infection. wild type mice showed a significant drop in peripheral blood oxygen saturation. Tmprss2/ mutant mice showed only a very mild change. infected wild type mice showed a strong increase in lung infiltrates and also in the number of infected cells. infected wild type mice showed a strong increase in lung pathology and reduced viral spread. TMPRSS2 is dispensable for cleavage activation of viruses with a multi-basic cleavage site. if resistance of Tmprss2 knock-out mice to H1N1 infection was indeed due to lack of HA processing, a virus with a multi-basic cleavage site should spread efficiently and cause disease. murine Tmprss2 activates HA proteins of viruses with a mono-basic HA cleavage site in infected host organism. the co-expression of protease and HA proteins of PR8M, HA4 and H3N2 viruses in transfected cells facilitated HA cleavage of all viruses. viral titers in infected mice were markedly reduced compared to wild type animals. however, no weight loss was observed in mutant mice in a dose-dependent manner. pathology is strongly reduced in Tmprss2/ mice after infection with H1N1 virus and diminished after infection with H3N2 virus. but unwanted side effects are a major concern. TMPRSS2 inhibitors may exert activity against diverse respiratory infections. the protocol used in these experiments has been reviewed by an ethics committee and approved by the ‘Niedersächsisches Landesamt für Verbraucherschutz und Lebensmittelsicherheit, Oldenburg, Germany’. the different virulence of PR8M and PR8F virus isolates has been described before [15] heterozygous mutant mice were interbred and wild type, heterozygous and homozygous mutant mice were genotyped by PCR analysis and then used for infections. expression plasmids encoding human and mouse proteases TMPRSS2 were published earlier [10], [13]. female mice at the age of 8–11 weeks were anesthetized by intra-peritoneal injection of virus solution in sterile NaCl. survival and body weight loss were monitored until day 14 p.i. mice with a weight loss of more than 30% of the starting body weight were euthanized. pelleted viral particles were lysed in 2SDS loading buffer. lysates were separated by SDS gel electrophoresis, blotted on a nitrocellulose membrane. membranes were stripped for 30 min at 50°C, washed 1 h with dH2O. sections (0.5 m) were cut from five evenly distributed levels of the paraffin blocks and stained with haematoxylin and eosin. sections were stained with a polyclonal primary antibody overnight at 4°C. tissue sections were incubated for 30 min with secondary antibody.
